More coverage
President Obama's second inauguration

Obama in address: Now is the time to act

President Obama placed his hand on a bible held by his wife as he was ceremonially sworn in for a second term by Chief Justice John Roberts. Tannen Maury/EPA
Obama took the oath of office during swearing-in ceremonies on the West front of the US Capitol. Brian Snyder/Reuters
The president delivered his Inaugural address, calling on a nation divided by sniping politics -- and a Washington split into bitter partisan factions -- to come together. Carolyn Kaster/AP
Throngs of people watch the president deliver his address after he was ceremonially sworn in for a second term as the 44th President of the US. Jim Lo Scalzo/EPA
Crowds gathered and celebrated in front of the Washington Monument near the US Capitol building on the National Mall while attending the public Inauguration ceremony. Mario Tama/Getty Images
Beyonce sang the National Anthem at the ceremonial swearing-in. Carolyn Kaster/AP
Obama spoke to his mother-in-law, Marian Robinson, as his daughters Sasha and Malia and his wife Michelle looked on during the ceremonies. Jewel Samada/AFP/Getty Images
Vice President Joe Biden took the oath of office-during the ceremonial swearing-in at the US Capitol while his wife, Jill, watched. Carolyn Kaster/AP
President Obama spoke to Vice President Joe Biden following the ceremonial swearing-in. Pablo Martizen Monsivais/EPA, Pool
The president greeted people on the West Front of the Capitol after the ceremony. Win McNamee/AP, Pool

  • Michelle Obama starts 2nd term in Thom Browne

Price paid for not running ball

There will be a rush to put this latest failure at the feet of Tom Brady, but the lack of a balanced attack is the reason the Patriots fell to the Ravens.

Former Harvard quarterback Vin Ferrara started Xenith LLC to make high-tech football helmets that attempt to minimize the possibility of concussions.
Opinion | Juliette Kayyem

Action on guns, immigration needed

The success of Obama’s domestic agenda in his second term depends on playing to both red states and the blue ones.

In surveillance, a new ballgame

Boston firm Bounce Imaging is developing a ball with six cameras inside for 360-degree viewing that can be used as a surveillance device for emergency responders.
Opinion | John E. Sununu

A crisis of values at MIT

As Aaron Swartz faced jail time, MIT remained silent. What happened to the clever, rebellious school?

Despite expert recommendations meant to encourage talks about end-of-life care, many still do not spend their final days the way they would have chosen.
